Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Precision Lasers for Controlling a Major Agricultural Parasite
Award.AbstractNarration: This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop and validate a novel solution for specific pests affecting honey bees. Beekeepers around the globe consistently cite Varroa mites as a leading cause of honey bee colony loss and, in the United States, attribute to these mites an estimated $2 B in agricultural damages every year. Since arriving in the U.S. in the late 1980s, Varroa mites have developed resistance to most known chemical pesticides, leaving beekeepers with few treatment options that do not also negatively impact the colony or contaminate honey. This project will develop a year-round, automatic, and chemical-free method for controlling Varroa mites, effectively mitigating the existing honey bee decline and resolving the chief problem facing beekeepers across North America and Europe, improving global food and agriculture supplies. <br/><br/>The intellectual merit of this project is the interdisciplinary application of selective photothermolysis technology combined with in-depth understanding of honey bee behavior to remotely detect and destroy a harmful apicultural pest. This project is investigating the field efficacy and cost effectiveness of employing a computer vision-driven identification algorithm to identify the Varroa mite, a serious honey bee parasite, and then introduce a high-power laser burst to immediately destroy the mite while it remains attached to the infested bee but without harming the host. The research objectives include quantifying the negative effect on mite population growth during the growing season and determining the number of laser/detector devices required to maintain permanent year-round control of Varroa mites in a standard colony.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Combplex has developed an automatic, highly effective, mite detection and elimination technology that automatically monitors and reduces mite loads in a colony year-round, providing a “drop and go” chemical-free alternative to regular miticide application. The Varroa mite is considered the most destructive parasite of honey bees worldwide, causing greater damage and leading to higher economic losses than any other known apicultural disease.

 Addressing this issue, Combplex’s patented sensor technology, the “Bee Laser Frame”, uses a stationary series of low-power red LED lights mounted to a frame positioned within the hive to detect reflectance differences between mites and bees. This allows for easy and reliable (94% detection rate) determination of a Varroa mite on a worker bee. If a mite is present, the device delivers a short laser pulse from stationary lasers, causing the mite to be fatally harmed while leaving both host bees and uninfected bees unharmed. In Phase I, Combplex demonstrated proof-of-concept of the Bee Laser Frame to accurately detect and eliminate mites within infested colonies, providing evidence that the technology is suitable for Varroa mite population control. Laboratory testing showed 90-95% of live Varroa mites expire within two hours after being hit with the Combplex laser, and field-testing results showed a significant correlation between the Bee Laser Frame and a reduction in mite population load.  Field testing also led to further understanding of real-world hive dynamics and colony variations, and how these changes affect the Bee Laser Frame performance.

This technology has a high potential to be the effective Varroa mite control beekeepers have struggled to find for over two decades. In addition to ensuring continuous chemical-free Varroa control, temperature and humidity sensors inside the Bee Laser Frame provide important monitoring data on hive health. Widespread colony health metrics will also provide an opportunity to produce novel honey bee data in orders of magnitude larger than anything available today, offering greater insight into honey bee health and best management practices. It is anticipated that this solution will prove more cost-effective than current treatments when considering the time and labor saved, increased colony production, prevention of colony collapse, and length of use (several years). The development and deployment of this technology will thus lead to lower costs and higher returns for beekeepers and healthier honey bees for U.S. hobbyist and commercial beekeepers alike. In addition, reduced Varroa-related colony loss will enable commercial migratory beekeepers in the U.S. to expand pollination services, which currently add an estimated $20 billion to the U.S. economy and supply critical pollination for crops such as almonds, apples, grapes, alfalfa, sunflowers, canola, and blueberries.
